Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Optical Tracking and Spectral Characterization of CubeSats for Operational Missions (OSCOM)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a short-term (one-year) effort to coordinate the development, testing, and implementation of a new optical tracking and spectral characterization system for CubeSat missions. Utilizing existing, newly installed telescopes at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University together with a real-time tracking architecture and analysis algorithms to be developed under this award the goal is the development of a capability to support mission operations on orbit for CubeSats by determining their physical characteristics such as spin, deployment mechanisms, and optical changes over time. The Special Purpose Inexpensive Satellite, named SpinSat, is a nano satellite developed by the Naval Research Laboratory scheduled to be deployed from the International Space Station in August 2014 and provides an ideal test case for the new system. Other NSF-funded CubeSat missions are scheduled for launch later in 2014 and will be used as additional test cases.

The new diagnostic tool will enhance CubeSat mission operations and help assess and address mission critical situations. Any improvements in satellite survivability, and increases in operational lifetime, will enable larger return from geospace science missions that use CubeSats to target outstanding unanswered questions in the space sciences, space weather, and aeronomy. Any changes observed in spectral characteristics of the CubeSat fabrication material over long durations will also provide valuable input for understanding that material?s survivability in low Earth orbit space environment. Once completed and tested, the project will make the design and source code for the new system freely and publicly available and distributed for use by the CubeSat and small-satellite communities. The system design, once released at project completion, will be a unique technical resource for use by a large number of student teams and academic institutions aiming to be engaged in impactful science and engineering.

In addition, the project offers a unique outreach opportunity to tie the field of astronomy with engineering and geospace science by educating young minds about CubeSats and their capabilities. ERAU hosts an Astronomy Open House every month where the general public is invited to peruse the university?s myriad telescopes, including the flagship 1 meter telescope. These opportunities will be leveraged to present to the general public exciting information about CubeSat and related technologies, as well as geospace science accomplished by small satellites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OSCOM Project Outcomes Report

 

The OSCOM project’s goal is to develop an optical tracking and characterization system specifically for supporting CubeSat and small satellite operational missions. CubeSats are small 10 cm cube-shaped satellites with a total mass of around 1 kg. The CubeSat design has become a popular method for universities and other entities to test new space technology before applying it to larger and more expensive satellites, as well as an educational tool for engineering in space environment. As the form factor of electronics shrinks over time, each generation of CubeSats become increasingly capable of performing real scientific research in areas such as space weather and aeronomy, and a proving ground of novel miniaturized technology. CubeSats are able to contain more complicated payloads by stacking multiple cube units.

Despite their popularity, CubeSats have suffered from mission failure rates of nearly 50%. The most common reason for failure is “no-contact”, meaning communication was never established between the satellite and a ground station. Power and communication system failures are the next most common causes of failure. These failures could be due to several reasons: uncontrolled spin, failure of antenna deployment, unfavorable pointing so that solar cells are not properly illuminated, or even incorrect satellite position information leading to the ground station antenna not pointing directly at the satellite. In such cases, optical tracking measurements are able to provide an independent confirmation of certain spacecraft physical features and parameters, such as spin rate and possibly attitude. OSCOM is a system designed to provide this key mission support information for small satellites via optical observation.

The year-long NSF supported effort involved three components: 1) optically and spectrally characterizing the Naval Research Laboratory’s (NRL) Special purpose inexpensive Satellite (SpinSat) on the ground before launch and observing it on orbit with ground based telescopes, 2) developing a real-time optical tracking system for observing a CubeSat-class small satellite in 4 color bands, and 3) developing analysis algorithms to potentially determine satellite spin rate and deployment information. Each component was successfully addressed during the project.

By optically characterizing SpinSat on the ground in 4 common color bands, we were able to establish a truth data set for comparison with our observations once it was on orbit. In the time before launch and during its initial phase of operations, considerable work was done to build and test the OSCOM optical tracking system. About two dozen observations of SpinSat by OSCOM were made by the end of the funding period. The OSCOM tracking system has also been used to make dozens of additional observations of satellites as small as 1.5U CubeSats. By monitoring the brightness of these small, unresolved satellites over time, OSCOM is able to determine their spin rate and identify antennae, instrument booms, and other unique markers that could provide rough attitude information, although algorithms for doing that analysis were not within the scope of this one-year effort. Special data reduction and analysis algorithms were developed to quickly analyze the raw imagery and provide accurate satellite brightness even as the satellite moves through the sky and the range to the telescope changes.  Methods were also implemented to directly extract possible satellite spin rates from the data.

This project supported one graduate student whose master’s thesis will discuss small satellite optical observations and detail the design of the OSCOM system.
